posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The original PS had a metric shitload of games, and in spite of growing up with it, I never played THAT many games for it (had maybe 15 PS titles). Recently I've been revisiting the console and there have been a lot of fun lesser known games I've been playing.

Lucifer Ring is a sword and sorcery type 3D beat em up, a little basic and by the numbers, but some of the bosses are awesome and beat em ups in this old world setting aren't too common.

Brigandine is a very flavourful strategy game with a fantastic art direction and sense of style. I guess with games like Final Fantasy Tactics on the system, Brigandine was bound to be overlooked, but it really is great.

Also been playing Ape Escape. That's not really a niche title, but I've never played it before. It is very impressively polished and well thought out, just in general. I'm looking forward to checking out the other games in the series.

If you have any recommendations, let me know. Otherwise, just post about the PS below. PS2 is cool too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9660908
It really depends on what you want the shader to accomplish. Some are more complex than others and emulate more facets of a CRT, while others are more simple and are made essentially to set them and forget them. That said, most of them are designed to be tweaked to your liking, so if you don't like how one looks right off the bat, you can usually go into the shader parameters and fiddle around and see if you can get it to look more pleasing. Speed may also be a factor if you're on a potato rig, and there's shaders for that, too.

That said, my recommendations are CRT-Guest-Advanced if you're a tweaker, as it has by far the most options and is still actively developed, CRT-Easymode if you just want something that looks alright and don't much care for parameter fiddling, and crt-gdv-mini if you're on a toaster, followed by zfast_crt if even that one is too slow, but we're talking memeberri pi levels of shit here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9665459
There's an element of that, but I think shader artists are trying to square a circle as best they can. What it comes down to is CRT being at its core an analog technology. It affects everything, even how frame rate works (modern monitors literally pause and hold the frame, they don't blast the field in and out leaving an afterglow the way a CRT would). The fidelity of the image is only limited by that of the human eye and the capacity of the tube. If you tone down the visibility of the scanlines to account for people seated at a healthy distance, then you get what probably just looks like a mild bloom effect. It's like trying to get the polaroid you took to look like the oil painting you saw in the museum. At the end of the day you're still looking at a polaroid and not a painting.
Something else people don't mention often is that it's one thing to imitate a CRT in a still image, but it's quite another to do it in motion. And I think that's almost certainly impossible for the above reasons. The concept of frame rate is very different for a CRT to that of an LCD. There are people trying to do black frame insertion on monitors with very high refresh rates and quite frankly that level of autism is too much for me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9665749
Makes sense. Wouldn’t there be some logic in trying for a mild CRT effect? Generally people just line double when playing on an emulator which gives an EGA/VGA sort of look but that seems inaccurate because the pixels are 480P size and every other line is blank. However the brighter pixels blend together to some degree, so trying to emulate this effect might be more accurate then simple line doubling. What is term for this, bloom? Seems like a good thing to approximate and not worry about creating intricate shadowmask or aperture grill simulatiors.

Personally I just have a 1080P display so I just line double and turn my sharpness down, but the idea of being able to use 4K shaders on an oled when I acquire one intrigues me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9665749
With ideal implementation and settings backlight strobing works very well for motion clarity but the flicker at 60Hz is somewhat harsher on bright solid colour blocks than a CRT. Nothing I can't overlook having grown up on 480i and games like GT4 with white menus but it's there and you don't want to look at white web pages or text editors in the dark particularly. But to get it perfect at any refresh it definitely kills brightness, which once again I can overlook because I am a cave dweller with my monitors turned down low anyways, and old CRTs without the brightness/contrast whacked up are not exactly the brightest things out there either anyways, but it's also something.

In general features to do a fairly good impression of a CRT exist but they aren't all together in one monitor let alone a practical or affordable combination of hardware overall.

And his biggest victory is just self-acceptance. Yeah Cloud is a dork but an extraordinarily determined one. One minute he's carving up WMDs created by the planet itself and the next minute he's complaining about motion sickness. He's a good character. Always has been.

>>9665532
I'm sure the Cetra used materia just in the same way humans did on account of them not knowing every little detail attributed to them. For example, Aries can use various magics as her limit break, but she still needs materia to cast "regular" magic. Any particular ancient might be able to commune with planet and know some of its secrets, but they still rely on materia for particularly esoteric stuff.

Not retro, but FFXIV goes with that explanation on its job crystals, which are lumped in with normal materia and auracite, the three being sort of three different degrees of the same thing. Materia has the least or most specific memories implanted in it, job crystals contain quite a bit more, and auracite contains not only the memories of a particular entity but also their pattern and form. If we applied this to FFVII, the black materia is likely a recreation of the specific steps needed to call down meteor.

Though I would say calling down a meteor on the planet sounds pretty odd for planet based magic. It's a spell drawing an entity outside of this world to the planet itself supposedly using the planet's energy to do so, it's not like a localized breech of the natural laws that most magic is. Though perhaps the black materia is entirely different from regular materia, being an entity foreign to the planet just like Jenova is which explains why you need so much energy to use it--planet won't aid in its use, and the only way Sephiroth/Jenova could use it was to suck up a lot of the lifestream and force its use as a conduit for it all.

>>9653016
It's not hard to make a Mame machine. But it's time consuming and the experience isn't the same as it was back in the 90s.

Arcade cabs usually had 1 game (unless it was a Neo Geo). And it played instantly when you dropped a quarter it in. No wait times or scrolling through tons of menus.

With Mame, people put thousands of games on their MAME machines. You walk up to a Mame machine and you can spend 10 minutes just scrolling through menus. Annoying and It really kills the vibe.

Plus you need to download roms, setup mame, fiddle with settings (which can take hours or days), test everything, tweak the controls to your likeing, and install a front-end (the pretty menu that you scroll through when choosing a game).

And worst of all, everytime Mame updates you need to re-download all your Roms again because the roms aren't compatible with the new version. I don't know why they haven't figured out a better way. If there's an error, then you deal with a lot Mame elitists who insult you and claim your an idiot. Even though Mame looks like it's still stuck in the era Windows 98. They havent updated their UI in decades.

When I want to play an arcade game, I don't want to use a computer. I want to instantly jump in the action. I don't want to deal with menus, error messages, or any other stuff that crops up.

I don't hate Mame and applaud the Mame team for preserving games. But I prefer original hardware when possible. It just feels better and less headache with setup.

Plus there are so many companies making hundreds of thousands if not millions by selling expensive custom arcade cabinets. Usually anywhere form $10K to 25K in price.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9653426
I've spoken with many old school arcade operators. I can offer some of their thoughts.

Some arcade machines kept track of how much they earned in the hidden operator test settings. Data would display on how much money/quarters that players put inside the machine on each difficulty. You could track the data.

If you made the difficulty too high, then casual players would give up and stop playing because it was too hard.

If you made it too easy, then the game wouldn't be seen as a challenge and your casual players would easily beat the on less quarters. Which means you earn less money.

The idea was to find the perfect middle ground. You could adjust default CPU difficulty on a scale from level 1 to level 10 in many games.

If your arcade was in an area with mostly casual players and children, then you kept the difficulty on moderate. You go easy on the kids to lure more quarters out of them. Give them just enough hope and they will give you more quarters.

For an arcade that had a lot of "pro players", operators kept the difficulty on high because they would be more of a challenge to pro players.

For some games like Fighting games, you could even adjust the default damage level.

For example, in the Philippines the the damage level was actually kept on 50% instead of the normal 100%. Kids didn't have a lot of money, so arcade owners would lower the damage so the players that visited often would be able to "feel" like they got their money's worth. Matches would be extra long due to lower damage. But this kept visitors coming to arcades. This happened in many countries in Asia, South America, and the Pacific Islands where kids had less money.

In America and Europe the damage was set to 100%

This led to an interesting scenario in "Marvel VS Capcom 2" when they were trying to host worldwide tournaments. Players argued on what should be the default damage level. Players spend their whole careers being used to a specific damage level.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653543
>This led to an interesting scenario in "Marvel VS Capcom 2" when they were trying to host worldwide tournaments. Players argued on what should be the default damage level. Players spend their whole careers being used to a specific damage level.

Part 2 - Continued

There was some arguments and debates on what should be the default damage level for worldwide Marvel VS Capcom tournaments.

As an Asian/Filipino/South American player, if you spent hundreds of hours (or even a few thousand hours) learning to play your team on a lower damage setting then your whole play style revolves around that damage levels. You know how EXACTLY much damage your character can take but still survive. Or How to recover, counter, etc. It will be very difficult to adjust to higher damage.

For players in America and Europe, you've trained your muscle memory to be able to execute the combos you need to exactly kill the enemy team with damage level set to 100%. If the damage level is set to 50%, then suddenly your combos that would kill the enemy team will still leave them alive.

So there were debates and arguments between players about it. I think the American Players and European players won out because... Well they are richer and put more money into hosting the tournaments. So they decided the rules.

Lightgun games have an hidden option called "Time to Death." Basically it guarantees the player will be hit X amount of times no matter what.

IMO after having played several games on real hardware and emulated, if the emulation of a game has become near flawless whether or not you beat it on real hardware is redundant. The only difference is that in a real arcade, you could be dealing with faulty buttons or a shoddy display, and perhaps the sound is so quiet that you can barely hear it. Emulated, you're using your own preferred display. Your own preferred controls. Even if it's a cheap fight stick, it's probably leagues better than the warn down HAPPs the arcade was using. If you want to go the extra mile you can just buy the game board and have the best of both worlds.

Does beating a game on easy mode count? Yes, because ultimately a simple 1CC on any difficulty is a casual achievement. Real hardcore players go for speed or score runs, where 1CC is just a mere requirement.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9658824
>>9658752
>I know this question is contentious and has no real answer, but how do you feel about the notion of completing a 1cc of an arcade game in a real arcade with the knowledge that said machine may actually be running on easy mode? Do you think it still counts?

First of all it must be real hardware. Emulation does not (and will never) count.

There is a reason that official record holder websites like Twin Galaxies and other websites exist. And the rule is that it must be on original hardware. It's to hold everyone to same rules and same standards.

Games like Donkey Kong require a 4 way joystick (original manufacturer design). And Using other joysticks with more available directions actually give an unfair advantage in game. There are active lawsuits right now in the real world about records being false because of using the wrong joystick.

PC computers are not universal. Everyone has different setups. Emulation can be used to cheat and there have been numerous cases of people cheating. Like with DDR and Guitar Hero record holders who've been caught faking their records. They record themselves with the gameplay speed reduced to around 90% or 80% (because they can't do it at 100% speed), then use a video editing program to speed it back up to 100%.

Or people trying to claim "Shoot Em up" or 'Run and Gun' game records, but use autofire. For example games like Metal Slug (even though it was never available in the arcades).

There are two rules when it comes to claiming records and achievements.

1. It must be on the same unmodified arcade hardware. Emulation is not accepted.

2. It must be on the same settings.

>easy mode
Are you trying to beat the game on easy mode? Then OK.

But if you want a higher difficulty, then politely talk to arcade technician/manager/owner to check the machine and change the settings. People politely ask all the time. It's not a huge deal. They might might even support what you are doing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9664341
Not quite. The multi-AV out is the same across all three systems, but only some SNES's have RGB outputs, European N64s and Gamecubes don't have S-Video, and the Gamecube component cable is actually a different connector only the Gamecube has.

There are some component cables for SNES's that just convert the RGB output, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I played fighting games on "real" Japanese arcade parts. The kicker is I didn't even know it at the time.
I owned one of these controllers: the Actlabs Arcade Rex.

These use the same switches used by Seimitsu during the time period: the Tokai MM9. With a 24mm button plunger. 24mm buttons were used on older Japanese cabinets during the 80s and early 90s and the AES controller.
The lever is a clone of the same lever found in the Neo Geo AES controller, and is a variant of the design used in the LS-33.
The balltop is a 30mm size just like the AES.

When I owned this stick I didn't appreciate it and wished I had the "real thing" in the form of a MAS stick.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9664341
Most models of the SNES have RGB output, but that's not component. You could connect it to something that accepts direct RGB or something like SCART, but you would need a converter (Or cables like these that have an in-line converter) to convert that to component.

If you want to output to a CRT then the Component route is your best bet, assuming you live in the Us where Scart is not common. If your end goal however is to output to a modern TV, then it would be better to just connect it by RGB/Scart to an HDMI upscaler. Even if your modern TV has component inputs, many can't handle the 240p signal the SNES would output through those, or they don't display interlaced frames properly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9661471
In the original game there were stone slabs that offered a riddle when you used the stone fragment from the same dungeon on them. Sometimes multiple slabs would be in one dungeon but they would all offer the same one riddle and it was often needed for you to figure out the puzzle it serves as a hint for.

In DX, all the stone slabs are replaced with owl statues BUT ALSO EXTRA ONES ARE ADDED which all offer NEW hints that weren't in the original game whatsoever. So one or two of the owls will provide the original stone slab hint needed to clear the dungeon while all the others offer superfluous obvious hints for stupid babies.

If the player recognizes that the owl statues are giving them superfluous obvious hints for stupid babies and they don't like that, they're likely to think, "These are all optional hint statues, I will skip them because I don't need hints." But then they'll skip, for example, the one that tells you which order to kill enemies in a certain room that otherwise has no indication of any kind that you need to do that to progress forward. In the original game that was the ONLY hint, presented as a riddle, intended to be read and interpreted in one room to solve a different room. In DX, that's ONE hint of SEVERAL and it's the only necessary one in a sea of bullshit hints you don't need.

>If all the dungeons from the original game are the same in DX, I don’t see how that would make a difference in clearing a dungeon.
I'm speaking, of course, of someone's first playthrough of the game. Using a guide or having the dungeons already memorized makes any point about bad design choices pointless, so I'm only speaking to the experience of someone on a blind first playthrough who won't know any better and might end up engaging with the game in a way that hampers their own progress and ultimately their enjoyment.

>>9661821
Pic related from Bottle Grotto. (forgive me for using the remake, it's all I could find on an image search)
The stone slab says, "First, defeat the imprisoned Pols Voice, Last, Stalfos..." Without that hint you would never know what to do in this room. It's not a really complex riddle or anything, but seeing that hint is necessary for solving the room because there's no other indication in the room itself and the Pols Voice being behind blocks makes it incredibly unlikely that you'd ever end up killing it first randomly and solving the order through luck. If you developed a habit of avoiding owl statues in the first dungeon, you'll be fucked in the second dungeon. In fact, I've seen threads in the past complaining about this very room and asking, "HOW WAS I SUPPOSED TO KNOW" and all that.

The problem is that in the DX version 90% of those stupid owl statues are just puzzle solutions for idiots rather than the original's single stone slab with one hint per dungeon. I don't think it's unreasonable for someone to avoid the owl statues if they rightly recognize them as a superfluous hint system, but since one of those owl statues will still provide the actual necessary dungeon hint like in Bottle Grotto (and it isn't specially marked or anything) that new player who just wanted to figure things out for himself gets punished for not playing on super-hint autopilot.

If someone is playing OG LA I would blame them for not reading the stone slab and say they should have simply engaged with the game more and done some thinking.
If someone is playing LA DX it's hard to blame them for wanting to avoid the overbearing hint system and it's the game's fault for allowing that to result in a player being confused.

Reminder that nearly every version of these early HP games were entirely distinct, completely unique games that shared nothing in common besides the obvious source material. Gameplay and level designs were all different.

>Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (PS1)
>Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (PC)
>Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (GC/PS2/XB)
>Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (GBC)
>Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (GBA)
All different games.

>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (PS1)
>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (PC)
>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (GC/PS2/XB)
>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (GBC)
>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (GBA)
All different games.

>Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (PC)
>Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (GC/PS2/XB)
>Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (GBA)
All different games.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
SRPG is a Japanese abbreviation (of English words), "Simulation RPG" -- it came about because the term "war simulation" was the genre term for war games in Japan, and for whatever reason the word "simulation" rather than "war" came to be used to abbreviate the genre. Then when they added named characters & experience points to it they called that a "Simulation RPG"

TRPG is an English abbreviation, "Tactical RPG" It came about because people thought SRPG stood for "Strategy RPG" and they didn't like that that didn't match the content of the games, which are about tactics. Either that or because Tactics Ogre and Final Fantasy Tactics were popular.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'd like to use a new term that applies to almost all FE games.

Puzzle Tactics game.

It's a "tactics" game where the emphasis is on "solving" a level by doing a very precise and rigid set of moves with very little room for improv.
To that end FE games tend to have side-objectives that emphasize rushing towards a part of the map where some unit is doing something on a "timer" so you have to immediately move a certain way with certain units to reach it. Also the weapon triangle makes it so very specific units can defeat other ones which are statically placed so you have to send a certain unit a certain way to accomplish that. Also the weapon triangle makes it so using a wrong unit can have them wiped out in even one attack, which reinforces the "correct" way of doing things and minimizes improv.

Games that would fit in this sub-genre are also Advanced Wars and (not retro) Into the Breach.

An example of a non-puzzle tactics game is Tactics Ogre, where you have more control over your party customization and loadout and the enemies can be defeated in a more fluid, back-and-forth way. Certain maps where you recruit special units are tailored mostly towards rushing them a specific way, but these are generally rare and special cases. In general you can flop around, lose some units, recover, and legitimately use "tactics" to win.
UFO and XCOM are also "true" tactics games.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9646353
>why are there so many tactics ogre/fft clones but so little fire emblem clones?
I suspect it's for the same reason that there are so many Castlevania clones and so few Metroid clones. Namely, that the majority of people don't fully appreciate the subtle differences between the two and so anyone asking for Metroid-like games is pointed toward Castlevania-like games as if it's all the same. Similarly, anyone who asks for Fire Emblem-like games is simply pointed to FFT-like games instead.

I think it comes from one game just being more popular than the other so that's what gets copied most and then people who don't respect the nuanced differences between the two don't drive any demand for copies of the less popular one because they don't even see a need for it.

>>9656819
>Well that's a perspective I've never heard before and does make the idea of just skipping to FE3 a lot more appealing.
If you only want to touch any form of that game once, then yes skip to Book 1 of Mystery of the Emblem. I will say there is a magic to FE1 that no other FE games have that I feel warrants at least one playthrough, though the inventory system might be frustrating to deal with as it is admittedly clunky. But there's a magic to playing the games in order of release and seeing the evolution there. Otherwise you would have to play half of a SNES game, go back to play Fire Emblem Gaiden on the NES, then go back for the other half of the SNES game to play in order of "1, 2, 3" for the games.
The inventory system might of the original Shadow Dragon might be frustrating to deal with, though. Even when the game wasn't even a year old yet there was an interview with the series creator on Famitsu and he talked about how people complained about that inventory system. So in the SNES remake he listened to the criticism and he overhauled it to be more easy to use and far less clunky.

They tend to have so many more playable units than there are deployment slots people just use their favourites and send everyone else to the bench, so it's not as if you're forced to use specific characters much.

And sure, you could argue those characters aren't always that different statistically, but you don't need to use especially specific class compositions either. You probably want a few staff-users and cavaliers, but when it comes to things like knights or archers, some people love them while others can't be bothered with them, and both get by just fine. You can take very different teams into the same map and come out on top. Not to mention sometimes a unit dies and you have to adapt to that. Sure you can reset, but not resetting or only resetting for really painful losses are definitely supported playstyles as well.

Regarding Advance Wars as well, maybe you only meant single-player, but AW has a big multiplayer community as well which doesn't seem plausible were it really a puzzle game.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9663743
The art design and music are brilliant, and the first stage is easily my favourite first stage in a collectathon. At the time, stages in collectathons were basically structured as gigantic amusement parks for the player to explore, so seeing them realise that on literal terms was brilliant. Having unique vehicles for every level was a nice twist on the Banjo Kazooie transformation formula, and makes traversing the levels fun, being empowered to fly around where previously you could only slowly move on foot (wheel). My main issue with this game is that the camera is genuinely terrible, and whenever I get to the Arabian world I feel like I’m just constantly fighting it and I just shelve the game. Overall though, it’s brilliant and I personally urge anyone with an N64 to give it a go.

In fairness, a couple things MML1 does that MML2 lacks:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9636792
>if you rewind before you got hit.. did you really learn how to dodge that attack?
Yes, because if you don't learn how to dodge it then you'll just get hit again and become stuck in a rewind loop until you learn how to not get hit. It's actually a much faster way to learn.

Without rewind, you either take the hit without dying and keep moving forward having learned little-to-nothing until next time or you die and restart the entire stage and have to replay until you get to the part where you died and try not to die.

With rewind, you get hit and then immediately rewind so you can analyze what hit you and why, then keep rewinding until you know exactly how to avoid it. It's the same practice loop as above, just done immediately instead of spread out over a long period of time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9638054
The post I originally replied to literally says:
>i eventually learn to beat it because i'm picking up on stuff and applying learned muscle memory to this difficult situation.
Which is all much more quickly learned through immediate repetition. It's the difference between improving your free throw in basketball by throwing 100 free throws each day and improving your free throw by playing an entire game of basketball each day. One gives you distinctly fewer repetitions of what you're trying to improve. You need to practice the whole game, too, obviously, but these individual fundamental skills are best improved through maximum repetition. If you want to master dodging a specific boss's attack then the best thing you can do is rewind repeatedly until you've got all the cues and timings down. Practicing the game as a whole is a separate thing with a different practice method.

>>9640856
Is it mental gymnastics to say that throwing 100 free-throws in a row is better free-throw practice than playing an entire game of basketball? The latter will take significantly more time but offer significantly fewer chances for a free-throw. If you want to practice beating one specific section of a game, it's better and faster practice to repeat that section over and over than to restart the entire game each time.

To use a more video game oriented analogy, competitive fighting game players go into practice mode and repeatedly practice inputs for the same move or combo repeatedly for long stretches of time. That way when the pressure is on during a real game they're less likely to drop their inputs. Playing a whole match is also practice, but if you want to practice one move the best thing to do is just repeat it over and over, same goes for rewinding a single segment repeatedly until you have it down.

posts.com:
In my opinion save states are only acceptable in the following circumstances:

- For NES era games that lack a saving function or credit system. Using a save state at the beginning of a world / set of levels instead of starting over from the very beginning.
- To suspend your game and pick up where you left off (like leaving your console on overnight)
- As a replacement for passwords as they can be a hassle to put in

Otherwise it's unacceptable. Rewinds are always unacceptable for obvious reasons, as there also isn't a cognitive learning process if you instantly rewind. Your brain won't learn the patterns like that, despite what some people claim here.

Fastforwarding in JRPG's is understandable, especially for the NES era. But I avoid them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653032
>Did it not occur to you while writing that training modes akshually make you worse
Not sure what you're referring to. All I know is that when you instantly rewind, there won't be a cognitive learning process as your brain needs to learn (adapt to) a certain pattern with expectations and outcomes. Rewinding just brings you back to the moment right before dying, but not the moments leading up to it. Yet you'll still receive the dopamine reward in both cases, taking away the motivation to become better at the game. Rewinding also drastically reduces the possibility of failure, and failure is when your brain actually learns in order to adapt and overcome. Hence the absence of learning.

8 and 16 bit games especially have been designed with this learning process in mind. It's the literal structure of those video games. When using save states or rewinds, you bypass this learning process and don't experience the game in full how it was intentionally designed by the brightest minds of the gaming industry. What you're left with is a powerpoint slide of dopamine shots that only serve as escapism. The element of 'play' almost completely disappears. Imagine soccer but every time a player misses he can rewind and slightly adjust his foot to make sure he'll get the right angle this time. What is left of the game then? Nothing.

In short, rewinding makes you a worse gamer in the long term. This is simple cognitive neurology, any scientist would agree. Save states and rewinds therefore make for an objectively inferior experience as you only experience a small aspect of the game. It's only slightly different than being a passive observer by watching a longplay on Youtube. It just baffled me how some people don't see this. I said my peace.

>>9664323
Devs make mistakes (and even if they didn't, they're constrained by resources and whatever platforms happen to be current). I agree with the AoE example; someone who only did that would almost certainly be depriving himself. On the other hand, a lot of Metroid Prime fans, especially those who played it "to the fullest", advise new players to use a walkthrough if the artifact hunt gives them trouble, because even though the rest of the game is good, that bit can suck. Yeah, they are missing out. On a bit that sucks. As someone who has 100% the game, I'm not going to hold skipping the sucky part against anybody.
Devs matter, but the final authority over what constitutes the optimal experience is the player. The Melee community sharply disagrees with Sakurai about how his game ought to be played, and they might smell funky but they seem to be getting more out of it than anyone else.

That's less sexual and more just matter of fact. The character wears underwear and if you make its model move in a position where you can see them, then you'll see them.
In the same way that there's nothing inherently sexual about mimicking breast jiggle physics, the sexual nature of it is more in the eyes of the viewer than the replication of some aspects of reality.

The alternatives are arguably more weird. Creating voids in the sprites, contorting the model in awkward positions, flatout removing the range of movement, changing the clothing style to not fit the character, or whatever else.
I don't fully understand why people assert underwear as inherently sexual when they're just another article of clothing and style that people and characters just happen to need.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
First time player here, played through Starcraft campaign and Terrain/Protoss portions of Brood War. First thing first, I am not into multiplayer because I am very bad when under pressure. I only played some Red Alert 2 on LAN with my friends 20 years ago. I don't care about esports and SC2. I am Westwood C&C fanboy and I have been hesitating to try Blizzard games for a long time. Tiberian Sun is my favorite and it is usually seen as thematically and visually close to Starcraft but now I see how different they are.
Campaign wise I still think that TS has better missions and maps. Neutral buildings, scripting, secrets etc. Starcraft missions are more like skirmish maps with minimum scripts. TS also has cooler technical stuff like deformable ground, debris doing damage, destructable bridges, working gates, flying units actually taking off and landing instead of always floating in the air. And tech tree looks more logical and less convoulted.
But the core gameplay of Starcraft is something else. Actually good hotkeys. So many rock-paper-scissor matchups, possibilities and little quirks. Marines on health-damaging drugs. Protoss units with rechargable shields and a building for fast charging. Zerg making suicide bombers out of humans. The joy of a Reaver drop and the chaos it causes. Manually building nukes and sending cloaked ghosts to guide them is actually fun unlike Tiberian Sun one click on cooldown superweapons. And the aforementiomed tech tree, while makes less sense in logical way, is less linear and greatly affects your gameplay choices.
Also I have noticed that Starcraft has some Dune 2 DNA in it that is not present in later Westwood games - upgrades, unit production facilities working in parallel, reliance on hotkeys (or visible command menu if you forget a key).
So, what's your opinion on Starcraft gameplay in comparison with C&C?

>>9663254
I agree with what you say, OP. The production value is higher in the TS campaign, on the whole, that is. But the story is better in SC, and the actual game balance and gameplay is better there as well. They both sort of fall apart when trying to be "difficult", though: because of the lack of unit balance, TS is won by mass producing whatever your strongest unit is and streamrolling the enemy, which is sort of boring. Similarly, the AI is not very good in SC but it builds quickly, so the way to win is to hotkey all of your production facilities (major design error: you cannot hotkey multiple of these at once until Warcraft III) and just sit in the base, growing your economy and spamming units to the front-line as fast as possible. This is more active, but it's the same on every mission with unit production available, and it's not very exciting because you aren't involved in the fighting at all; you only periodically have to go to the battlefield to regroup forces that are standing around.
Wait until you get to Warcraft III, that's the peak of RTS to me and it isn't even close. Even with its flaws.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9660109
The remaster is fantastic and the most accessible legit way to play the game unless you have a GameCube copy or manage to get your hands on a copy of Trilogy. The visuals and controls are great, and the sounds, music, progression, map layout and overall content are 1:1 to the original, unlike the Dead Space remake. Essentially, if you play the remaster, you're getting the full experience, and a good representation of it at that.

If you're a purist and want something closer to the untouched experience, download PrimeHack for Dolphin and play the Trilogy through that. Also a great way to play all three games. But keep in mind that the Trilogy lacks some of the minor touches the original GCN edition had.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9660146
The new controls are certainly more intuitive, but the game was originally designed around the more involved aiming controls and stuff. So when you play the remaster with twin stick control, it's super fucking easy. Like I am on Normal and have not come even close to dying at any point. I think the remaster supports a control option that mimics the original though, but I haven't tested it. It also has the Wiimote aiming controls if you're into that. If you have a Switch-compatible GC controller, it can be used to control the game exactly as it was on the original hardware. Visually the remaster is exceptional, and runs at 60FPS somehow despite the Switch's dogshit hardware.

Ultimately, I would recommend the remaster without any caveats, unless your mission is specifically to play the original code of the game in its purest form. The remaster is a straight visual upgrade without sacrificing any of the original's art direction or atmosphere. Control options are varied enough to give you whatever you want. It's got extra accessibility options, and some bonus features like concept art and 3D model viewers that the original didn't have.

TL;DR The remaster is definitely worth the purchase

>>9661350
In Halo CE & 2 Anniversary you are essentially running two layers of graphics over the same engine and the layer you aren't using is culled, when you toggle you are just flipping what's culled. There's still noticeable lag on most setups when you turn the remastered graphics on because the game has to run all the post-processing effects, which ironically wouldn't be noticeable at all if the remaster graphics were designed with Halo 3 and ODST's philosophy of heavily using prebaked lighting and contrast instead of post-processing, but that's a tangent.
The reason they can do this is because Halo's game engine is actually hilariously simplistic, Blam is super basic. Something like UE would chug hard running two sets of full graphics layers for remaster graphic flipping, I think.

You bought it on Steam I presume? The Steam version lets you switch between classic and remastered modes on the fly by pressing the Tab key. Classic and remastered modes otherwise play identically, though.

The Steam version in classic mode is the definitive way to play the game, it has 60fps and online co-op too. There are however three advantages in the original Xbox version from 2001:

>In fact, the loading screens on Xbox are the most kino thing you'll ever see

The MCC is a disrespectful remaster.

But the worst of all is that they removed the Bungie teams from the credits of the games they made. Really they removed the credits sequences entirely, including from Halo 4, and have the credits on their website which you can access through a link in the game. Frankly disgusting.

posts.com: At first it seemed better than the Sega arcade port, I really liked the level on the raft, the real sensations of adventure, alternative gameplay. Cool level with columns. The levels are 2 times longer, so the walkthrough longer, the checkpoint is only in the middle. The last stages are made according to the residual principle and copy the last GnG, you just climb a few stairs and at the end the boss of the first game. The bosses are made in a balanced way, there is no checkpoint in front of them, so they are easier, except for the last ones on the second run. There is a level in the gut of a ghoul, like in Earthworm Jim, quite original, you are twisted around the level, like in Super Castlevania 4, then you ride on a platform through gases, the most boring thing is that they do not show how you get there and how you get out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The weapons were spoiled here, there is no strike in 4 directions, this is the same degradation as after SuperCastlevania 4 and Bloodlines. It’s mostly bad weapon here, thr boomerang, the Death scythe from a castlvania, the torch, the axe with a strange spiral trajectory, there was so better in the prequel. In fact, only the starting spear, the classic knife, the imba crossbow and the saintball for the second run are usable. Saintball is also a terrible shit, although it is strong, you can only throw one, on the half of the screen, the farther, the weaker. In GnG it was much nicer, like magic from the end of the gothic. With it, it is almost impossible to pass the boss Satan from the first and second games. It's hard to even get to them, the red devils start to cause problems like in the first game.. The game just broke me, I made a savestate before the bosses. Even with it, I spent dozens of attempts, he needs 30 strokes, I'm fucked up. All bosses are easily taken out with a crossbow, especially magical ones, you just smear Satan on the first try, you spam with arrows without stopping. The game is broken if you are forced to walk half the game with the worst, but quest weapon.
The mainboss is similar to Loki from the prequel, but a little more complicated, you need to understand how to jump on one platform, after a few trays you can kill him. He even upset me after this Satan, I freaked out, skiped with a savestate, but immediately replayed it so that there was a sense of completeness.
In general, its good game, beautiful graphics, original levels, but the weapons of the second run and real meinbosses are very annoying. 8/10

>>9660713
There are better sites, which have more strictly curated abandonware with well designed launchers - like TCC. Myabandonware is curated, and there are hundreds of links to paying sites for many games now, but there's so much content on here that it's always going to be behind.

In terms of the 'is it legal/is it not' - no it's not legal, but rather than being "illegal" it's what one may consider "unlawful" - i.e., it's unlikely that anyone is going to do anything about it, . Similar things for instance would be the 'street drinking beer in paper bag' example from the Wire - Police don't want to arrest you, but it's illegal - if they can't see it they don't have to arrest you.

The police or your ISP certainly aren't going to bang down the door, as it's a waste of resources. This of course all changes if someone with the copyright starts using it again, and can potentially make money off you having downloaded it.

There's no legal definition of abandonware and the download and distribution of software that is considered abandonware is still considered theft/piracy. There's no rule under copyright law where a product eventually just becomes free.

The thing is that abandonware is by abandonned by "definition" and such the owners of the software are unlikely to pursue legal action, if they even exist, or if anyone even knows who still owns the software, and there's no vigilantes going around defending the honor of abandonware. The copyright of abandonware should basically be considered equivalent to an unenforced law.

But anyway all that is a moot point because no one gives a fuck about pirating games at all, abandonware is only special because "getting away with it" doesn't even begin to describe how easy it is to host and distribute abandonware.

It's Black Matrix 00. What a fucking weird series this is though.

Black/Matrix - Saturn - 1998
Black/Matrix AD - Dreamcast - 1999
Black/Matrix + - PSX - 2000

Black/Matrix II - PS2 - 2002

Black/Matrix Zero - GBA - 2002
Black/Matrix 00 - PSX - 2004

Weird seeing Ryoko Shiraishi and Nana Mizuki in a PSX game, but it was the last new Japanese game for the system. I mean, releasing PSX games after the PS2 was out was not a totally unreasonable thing to do because of backwards compatibility meaning you were purely expanding your install base, but that's so deep into the next generation for Japan after they'd already made a PS2 game in the same series. But the PSX port coming after Dreamcast was already an odd start.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9664239
>The setting
>The music
Probably the claims of yours I come closest to agreeing with. The music is top notch and the setting isn't one of the best to me (tropical islands! medieval fantasy! odd collection of random crap like casino cruise, rock stars, and aliens because it's a kitchen sink too!) but it's still pretty nice.

>the characters
There are 45 playable characters. They are not all very memorable (many are just kinda there) nor are they even fully unique. The few NPCs (since nearly everyone gets recruited anyway) aren't much better, with most of them being pretty clear JRPG cliches. This doesn't make THEM bad - I prefer a lot of the NPCs to some of the PCs - but they're not an A+. The good ones average to Bs, add in the shittier PCs and we drop a full letter grade.

>overall tone
HUMANITY BAD BECAUSE THEY DESTROYED THE ENVIRONMENT. HUMANITY MUST BE BERATED FOR THEIR KILLING AND DEPREDATIONS THAT ARE ENTIRELY UNIQUE TO THEM. PREPARE TO BE YELLED AT BY FAIRIES FOR GENOCIDING THEM EVEN AS IT'S DWARVES DOING IT, BECAUSE ONLY HUMANS ARE MURDERERS DESPITE ALL EVIDENCE TO THE CONTRARY.

>plot progression
It's good until you become Lynx, then almost all sense of momentum is lost and you just kinda dick around until it's time to get your body back, and then every NPC decides it's time to recite a novel's worth of infodumping that could have been spaced out better through all the rest of the stuff.
Chrono Cross would be an average JRPG even if it weren't a sequel, and that's okay! Average is better than bad! Average things can be your personal favorite things because we all have different interests and it doesn't mean you have bad taste.
But it does mean it's kinda silly to insist that it's an all-time great when it has plenty of legitimate flaws that prevent other people with different - but still good - taste from calling it "top of all-time best".

>>9664348
I think the complaints about the playable characters reveals the value of actual NPCs. The Cross roster is what you'd get if the NPCs in Trigger joined you after their role in the story ended. Get the Jet Bike Key from Doan after the Guardian fight? Doan joins you. Found not guilty at the trial? Pierre joins you. Rescue Fritz? Fritz joins you. Ayla offers to rescue Azala? Azala joins you. Meet up with Alfador in the last village? Alfador joins you. Gaspar asks to join your team? Gaspar joins you.

This sounds fun on paper but since all these characters have served their purpose it means them becoming playable is when they're at their least interesting. Plus their skillsets overlap so there's little reason to use everyone.

posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9665285
Same, I've always liked games with giant casts. Finding a new character to join your party is one of the most satisfying things you can find in an RPG. Even if their skillsets overlap and there's really no need for that many characters, it's still fun playing around with party combinations and trying out their moves. Recruiting party members is a simple pleasure like collecting action figures as a kid. I wouldn't want every game to have it though, >>9665276 makes a good point about if you shoehorned it into CT.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9665285
It does create a pacing problem. Trigger's story is so lauded because every character's arc gets set up and then resolved alongside the main story. You can't do that when you have 45 characters. It results in a clear divide between "important" characters and everyone else. Fargo gets a lot more than Irenes. And then characters like Janice and Pip are just Pokemon to collect. Then you get characters like Razzly who have maybe 5 minutes of story relevance despite clearly being more interesting than that, leaving you with plot blue balls.

>>9654834
Nintendo for some reason doesn't care about dinosaur games. My experience with Wii, Wii U, 3DS, and Switch is that with Wii they had the most support ever, with Sega, Hudson/Konami, SNK-Playmore pitching in games for huge line up of retro consoles. Maybe licensing is too much these days or they'd rather just release their own overpriced compilations.

Wii U and 3DS support was kind bad, and I think PC Engine was Japan only. Maybe MSX, can't remember. And even so it was less games than the Wii service.

All the "big" retro games on Switch already have their own physical or digital collection by their own publishers. Tons of arcade games exists through Hamster and their arcade releases on the eShop. They have a huge range of stuff that has never been released in a long time but they're like $8 per ROM with online leaderboards a few standard options. Oddly Sega has a Genesis/MD collection AND a few of the same titles on the Switch Online Expansion. There's an official Switch Genesis/MD wireless controller but there's also the official USB controllers from retrobit that work on the Mini console and Switch dock.

So for me I don't keep my hopes up for retro games coming out on these online services. Yeah we should be getting a month of month or one a week but their focus is really just physical/digital new games.

What's the general consensus on this game?
Honestly I wasn't impressed. I know that it's SNES and 3D games were a novelty, but it was often really hard trying to understand what the fuck was going on onscreen. And it didn't help that the game was constantly trying to force me on a first person perspective that made things even worse. The gameplay felt really simple, exceedingly so, except some of the bosses, that were annoying in a gimmicky way. The scoring system seemed completely meaningless, or broken. I assume the sequels would fix many of these things, but is the first game regarded as a classic, or more as a tech demo that I think more accurately describes it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9662417
If you unpack an ISO and then just casually repack its contents into a brand new ISO, chances are the formatting will be nowhere near what a PS2 game is actually expecting, and PCSX2 will then shit its pants when you try to run it.

What I can recommend without getting into software that you have to pay for to spoof disc formats and such, is a little bit of patience and a hex editor. Specifically, HxD if you are on Windows. You can use HxD to directly modify the ISO contents without completely screwing the formatting up. Just copy paste the new file contents in and you should be set. Things could get complicated if the file sizes do not match though, so watch out for that. I would recommend to minimize chances of breaking things that you use the Tools > Open Disk Image option rather than directly opening the ISO.

>>9662545
Because an engineer was taking his old music and converting it for Moonwalker. The Mega Drive game is an imitation of his work, not an original.

Sonic 3's OST was going to be an original composition from him, meant to stand on its own, and he wasn't satisfied with the results.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9663473
Brad Buxer has a lot of involvement with all the tracks because he was part of Jackson's production crew. It was not like he was independently hired to make the music for ice cap zone. Partly, the reason why SEGA hasn't paid to get the music back is it's too legally ambiguous to work out who owns any of the tracks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9662545
From what I understand, by the early 90s Jackson was moving away from the heavy synth sound of his music from the 80s to something with heavy sample usage. Moonwalker worked alright on the Genesis because the FM chip was analogous to the synths used in a lot of his songs (on a primitive level anyway), but I think by Sonic 3 he was more focused on making music with an emphasis on samples (you'll notice that the tracks worked on by his soundteam in Sonic 3 have a ton of unique samples to them compared to the rest of the soundtrack). But of course the Genesis only has a dinky little 1-channel DAC for sample playback that relies heavily on the CPU for playback, and that combined with the low storage space meant instrument samples sounded harsh and robotic.

tldr: changing tastes in music production and poor sample playback on the Genesis is likely the reason MJ pulled out of Sonic 3, in terms of disliking the soundchip.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9663872
Though, I think the real reason is that simple didn't have the time to crank out a full soundtrack, considering how time crunched Sonic 3's development was and how seemingly late the MJ music was implemented into the game (the earliest proto from like 2 months before the final build still doesn't have any of the MJ music).

posts.com:
I just finished F.E.A.R. It was alright.
Lots of people have said the AI is amazing, but I don't think so. Most of the callouts they would shout would be just plain wrong. The way they split into cover and tried to get behind the player was nothing groundbreaking either. No more complex than what elites did in Halo.
The shotgun was certainly fun to use, but little of that was in the gun itself - all the feedback is in how the enemies gib. Which is excellent to see in slow motion.
The rest of the roster of guns was plain, so I found myself using the shotgun most of the time, with the particle rife for tougher enemies.
Speaking of those - there wasn't nearly enough variety. Occasionally you'd get one of those heavily armored troopers. Or a bunch of drones together. But I think the combat would have been better served by mixing between things more often. Instead, it was just room after room of guys who are ready to be gibbed by the shotgun, posing no threat.

How do the sequels shape up compared to it?

>>9653279
The expansions have a pretty common bug where roughly halfway through Extraction Point the game will start crashing during loading the next level. But the new weapons are very satisfying to use at least.

I got around the issue by setting all graphics settings to the lowest and putting them back to full after successfully loading into the next level.

>>9653108
The lack in enemy / sequence variety is my biggest gripe, followed by the extremely slow jogging speed of the main character. One of the reasons why I love Half Life 1 so much is because it switched up it's setpieces and gameplay dynamics around a lot. One moment you're jumping over moving industrial machinery, then you're fighting grunts in literal trenches and machine gun positions, powering up railroad tracks so you can drive a cargo locomotive through the transportation system.

The base game FEAR also does a decent job of pacing the experience with NPC dialogue and meeting up with your team so even if the gameplay remains samey, there are some things to direct your interest other than just the shooting. Some parts of the expansions are better than others, like the parts of XP where you team up with a Delta Force guy are better than the sections where you go through long stretches alone without even the comlink guy talking to you. But each to their own.

>>9653108
FEAR definitely has issues. Most notably the repetitiveness... you can play the first few levels and that's about all the game's got to offer for a maximum of 7 or so hours.
You're fighting in impossible office spaces and sewers, and that's about it. They're very blocky (fine, accomodates the AI) and not very interesting to look at.
The Shotgun is about the only gun you need. Having a powerful shotgun is great, but many games get the Doom 2 syndrome, where the main powerhorse is so powerful and versatile, that there is very little incentive to use other weapons.
Doom pwads (not much Doom 2 itself lol) such as Plutonia will require the player to switch up weapons to fit drastically different scenarios, to avoid this issue and generate variety. FEAR never really does that. The other 2 weapon choices only exist in case you run out of shotgun ammo.
Not a game I care to replay, but a good experience and one of the best of the generic FPS at the time.
Also, Halo Elites really were peak AI. One of the most fun enemies to fight in vidya, period. I'm surprised people love to mention FEAR's but never Halo's, which was even more impressive, and made years earlier.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9653108
FEAR's AI was not all that special under the hood, but Monolith designed the whole game around its strengths and made enemies more agressive than your average shooter at the time had. Together with some neat features like it being able to hop through windows, and great sound design (combat communications of the clones and their lines changing to nervous and panicking when they lose more than half of the squad), it made them stand out. In one of the expansions, i think it was Perseus Mandate, third party devs tried to make fights in open areas with AI companion, and it looked awful: just bots standing and shooting other bots because they didn't have paths to go anymore.
>I found myself using the shotgun most of the time, with the particle rife for tougher enemies.
Same here, except i held to dual pistols for as long as i could find ammo for them and heavies weren't so common. Great for headshots.
>How do the sequels shape up compared to it?
Everyone is saying 2 is better than 3 but i just can't play it after the first game. Guns have no feedback, enemies are lit like a Christmas tree with some stupid looking neon appliances, they go in waves like in CoD, control scheme is weird with limited remapping options and with goddamn mouse acceleration (leftovers from it being a console first title, thank God there is a fix for mouse on PC)... Oh, and there are lots of text messages that you need to read from menu instead of audio logs, and it is not like they are all that interesting to read. I just don't know, i didn't play it more than a couple of hours because of how bland it seems.
I didn't even touch 3, but seen some videos on it lately, and it honestly seems more interesting than 2, especially with the option to play as Paxton, hopping between posessed enemies. The coop mode when you needed to outrun the wall of darkness seemed interesting too, but i guess it is long dead.

Yeah the biggest problem with FEAR is the lack of variety in both enemies and locations. Having a shootout in an office building and seeing it get trashed is super fun at first but when you spend like half the game there it gets fairly dull. I'm also not a big fan of how slow you move. Seems counterintuitive to having these cool melee kung-fu moves when your top movement speed is a light jog. It's why Trepang2 is probably the indie shooter I'm most interested in, it doesn't even try to pretend its not a ripoff but a game that's just FEAR with better movement options and more diverse locales sounds like a pure upgrade on paper.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9650637
If you haven't installed Q-Zandronum for SNS already, you should do that now. Being a distinct fork of Zandronum, you'll also have to rebind your keys.

The server will broadcasted to the master.qzandronum.com:15300 master server, so your doomseeker should be configured to fetch servers from there. The doomseeker that came installed with Q-Zandronum should be pre-configured for this, so you can just use that. I noticed that having the server set to favorites will erroneously display it as a Zandronum 3.1 server instead of a Q-Zandronum one. If you get this error, just remove the server from your favorites, close doomseeker, wait a minute, then re-open doomseeker. That should be everything.

>>9651834
California is a crooked fucking place, this kind of shit isn't very rare. District Attorneys and prosecutors are also notoriously predatory as is.

Rojas doesn't even really have an audience either, is the thing. He was mostly active modding Wolf and Doom in the 1990s and early 2000s, and he left his mark with that stuff, but it was never the highest profile. He moved on to other things, also, trying to pursue acting and writing, where he didn't have very good luck.
For the majority of these fandom's time, he's mainly remembered by older users one of the early pioneers who moved on, he's not one of those guys who stuck around all this time and remained a prolific contributor, or one of those who came around to check things for a while every few years.

The most exposure he's had in a long while was all the way back in 2016 where he had an interview with Vice which paints him as struggling and unsuccessful, not touching much on his videogame stuff, telling of recent misfortune, which then snowballs the fuck out of control.
It feels rude to say, but he's a has-been in these communities, and he's not famous for anything else, faint threads to old times is essentially the one ship he could signal to when lost out at sea with no other rescue, so to say.

Not gonna lie, there's a niggling worry in the back of my mind that this could be a con, either just Laz himself, or possibly he died in prison while awaiting his trial, and someone is assuming his identity, maybe exploiting an otherwise true story. He's had his identity stolen before, got basically robbed back in 2017, and with rotten luck like his, I can see it happening to him even after death, the guy's been rolling snake eyes for a decade.

I only tossed him some pocket change, so I don't have much at stake, but so far, it's all believable.
As I said about Cali, the place is rotten and the criminal justice system is a massive farce, so far I'm not sensing any rank odour of bullshit from this story.

>>9657759
Gonna second the other guy.

A full one-man megawad can be quite daunting though, a lot of people set out to do that early in their mapping career, but then find that they don't have the steam to go through with it. If you find yourself losing your drive halfway through, or like the levels feel like obligations, then consider if you can just plain wrap it up. Consider also that there are many levelsets which aren't even 10 maps long yet are classics still getting enthusiastic recommendations, and that with UMAPINFO, so much of the game's structure is on your terms, a set of maps which end at 10 don't need to unceremoniously spit the player out into O' Of Destruction.

Not saying don't, there's some good one-man megawads out there, it can be worth it, just that you shouldn't feel like you have to force yourself.

The idea is that Nightmare should be an extension of Hard, giving players less room to make health-costing mistakes while still letting them use the muscle memories and techniques acquired from lower difficulties against enemies who still function as the player is used to.

But I also think it's a dumb change. Nightmare should be Nightmarish. It shouldn't need to be a glorified Hard+, it's a secret skill level that's accessed by exploring the starting hub and makes enemies act almost exactly like they do in the Doom skill of the same name. It also allows mappers to make levels that are designed specifically for these psycho turret enemies and can remix existing levels by forcing the player to progress through them entirely different.

I don't know why this Copper change in specific was implemented in the rerelease. Maybe they thought console players would find it impossible.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9662321
I think that would probably be an effective way to balance the original behaviour and your idea in a way that doesn't change the dynamic the current enemies have as a whole too drastically.

If it was the other way round, that would potentially trivialise pain elementals since the lost souls they spawn would most likely die as soon as they spawn (since they're usually already charging right?) and do splash damage to the pain elemental too.

I think you would probably have to do it that way in the end anyway because of how the change might affect pain elementals.

I dont know Doom well enough to think of any specific examples of how that would affect the gameplay in context. But I'm making a map atm and in one section there is a monster closest with probably about 20 lost souls and two pain elementals, and I think that change would make that trap significantly less intimidating.

It's in an open area and I like how the lost souls force you to focus on them, but the pain elementals are replenishing them so you really want to try to get them first. It's like being swarmed by flies while fighting someone. It forces you to dance around.

But with the change you're suggesting that might make it so you can one shot a single lost soul and start a chain reaction that would kill all of them in just one shot.

I mean this is my own map I'm talking about so take that with a hefty pinch of salt. But that's one situation I can think of where that behaviour change would probably remove all the danger from a fight that normally has the potential to overwhelm the player.

I don't think that's a problem with the idea itself, just how it effects that example of level design with the original behaviour in mind.

What about if they only explode when they're a certain distance from the player? So same idea, if you shoot them while charging they explode, but that only happens when they are within 256 units or so.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653254
It's an extremely basic map. I found no bugs but I'll try and point out numerous weird looking or nonsensical parts. The moai face itself doesn't really look anything like a moai since the proportions are wrong, it's very jagged and beige for some reason. The spaceship thing looks more detailed but It makes me question what the theme is supposed to be. The geometry is too simple and devoid of lighting everywhere else. The wood ceiling that's completely flush with the sky by the red key area looks wrong since it implies the ceiling is ridiculously thin. The blood pools that rise when you enter them serve no mechanical purpose at all. The extensive use of sound blocking lines is weird and makes the monsters look especially dumb. If you want to divide up areas it's generally better to use distinct rooms separated by doors/lifts etc. and to give monsters the ambush flag while positioning them in a way where they won't immediately see the player. The optional plasmagun area feels pointless since there's another plasmagun nearby. The teleporter in the lava pool is pointless since the surrounding floor is short enough to walk back up. In general it feels like there's an excess of ammo and health for what you're up against. Whenever releasing a map for playtesting it's a good idea to specify what port it was designed for and tested in. It's also advisable to add new midi music. In the future I'd say you should look more closely at some other people's maps which you like and try to emulate their design and aesthetics.
